STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
July 13, 2020
Darnell Britt
Community Care Organization
18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
RE: License #: CB820315857
Investigation #: 2020C0108050
Community Care Organization
Dear Mr. Britt:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-4532
enclosure
LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820315857
Investigation #: 2020C0108050
Complaint Receipt Date: 06/11/2020
Investigation Initiation Date: 06/11/2020
Report Due Date: 08/10/2020
Licensee Name: Community Care Organization
Licensee Address: 18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
Licensee Telephone #: Unknown
Administrator: Darnell Britt, Chief Administrator
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington, Designee
Name of Facility: Community Care Organization
Facility Address: 18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
Facility Telephone #: (313) 920-4268
Original Issuance Date: 07/30/2013
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 01/30/2020
Expiration Date: 01/29/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
CA 1 assaulted IL Youth G No
Men broke into the provider home and stole IL Youth L’s Undetermined
belongings
Additional Findings:
IL Youth destroy property in the homes and steal each other’s Yes
belongings. IL Youth L’s laptop and clothing were stolen from the
home on Lakewood. The youth are expected to protect their own
property. A lock on a window at the Lakewood location has been
broken and repaired by the agency multiple times. Over the
years, several televisions have come up missing from the provider
homes, suggesting safety issues and a lack of appropriate
supervision of the youth in the homes.
An in-person home visit or video conference by the IL worker was Yes
not documented for one IL youth in April 2020
Chief Administrator (CA) 1 pushed IL Youth G's head through a window.
IL Youth D stabbed a man and a former IL youth after they broke into the provider
home on Lakewood Street in Detroit between 7am - 3pm. IL Youths J and L
cleaned up the blood.
III. METHODOLOGY
06/11/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0108050
06/11/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Letter
Requested information from agency's assigned DCWL Licensing
Consultant re: alleged perpetrator's role at the agency
06/12/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Left message with Government Agency Supervisor inquiring about
Government Worker assignment; no Government Worker
assigned as the youth is a legal adult
2

06/15/2020 Contact - Document Sent
Emailed Licensee Designee (LD) 1 requesting last names,
birthdates and IL worker's names and numbers for all IL youth
identified in complaint
06/15/2020 Contact - Document Received
Received requested information from LD 1
06/15/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Spoke with LD 1. Requested MISACWIS person ID numbers for
all IL youth involved, requested names of IL workers assigned, all
IL youth have had various IL workers over the past 4 months, the
LD is also the house manager and covering as an IL worker
06/16/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Attempted to contact IL Youth G for interview; no answer
06/16/2020 Contact - Document Received
Searched MISACWIS SW home visit contacts in 2020 for IL Youth
involved
06/16/2020 Contact - Document Received
LD 1 notified me that IL Youth G has been AWOL since 6/11/20
06/16/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Attempted to contact IL Youth J for interview; left message
06/16/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed LD 1 re: allegation 2
06/17/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Reached IL Youth J, he was busy and could not talk
06/17/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Left message for IL Youth D
06/18/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Left message for IL Youth J requesting a callback
06/18/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed IL Youth D by phone
06/18/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed IL Youth G by phone
06/25/2020 Contact - Telephone call received
3

LD 1 tried to arrange phone interviews; states that the three IL
youth pending interviews are not available and left the home prior
to 8:45am today
06/29/2020 Contact - Telephone call received
LD 1 arranged and private phone interviews were conducted of IL
Youths D and J at 8:30am; IL Youth L was unavailable
06/29/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed CA 1 regarding allegation of assault
06/29/2020 Contact – Telephone call received
Interviewed IL Youth L
06/30/2020 Contact – Telephone call made
Re-interviewed LD 1 re: allegation 2
06/30/2020 Contact – Telephone call made
Interviewed IL Worker 1
10/20/2020 Exit Conference with Area Manager, assigned Licensing
Consultant, investigating Licensing Consultant, LD1 and CA1
attending
ALLEGATION 1:
Chief Administrator (CA) 1 pushed IL Youth G's head through a window.
INVESTIGATION:
IL Youth G, age 18, has resided at the provider home on Lakewood Street in Detroit for
eight months. I interviewed him by phone on 6/18/20. I asked IL Youth G if CA 1
pushed his head through a window. He responded “I’m good with that incident. It did
not happen.” Asked what did happen, IL Youth G said he and CA 1 “got in an
altercation.” I asked him to elaborate. He responded “I don’t know much. I choose to
let all that stuff go in the past. Was that all you wanted?” I asked IL Youth G to
describe the incident so the state can assure his future safety and that of other youth in
the program. He said, “I just don’t remember. I was acting a fool. Where was that
again? Where was it (where did it happen)?” The phone went dead. I am uncertain if
there was a bad connection or the youth hung up.
Chief Administrator (CA) 1 has been the Administrator for the Community Care
Organization Child Placing Agency since its inception in 2013. I interviewed CA 1 by
4

phone on 6/29/20. I asked if he pushed IL Youth G’s head through a window. He
responded “No. That did not happen.” I asked if he recalled an incident with himself
and IL Youth G. CA 1 said, “We, um. He, um. We were having a discussion. IL Youth
G got irate and hit me in the mouth. I just tried to stop him from hitting me. I had just
gotten a hip replacement. We were struggling. We both landed into a glass partition
the Matrix Center…It’s a community center. It was my first time meeting him. He
walked up on me. He flinched at me and took off his jacket. I had my arms extended
out. I stepped back. He tried to hit me with his right arm. We started to tussle and
ended up by the steps. He tried to push me down the stairs. We landed into the glass.
He hit me in the mouth. Former Staff 1 grabbed him…My lip was busted. IL Youth G
was not hurt.”
I asked CA 1 if any other IL Youth or current employees from Community Care
Organization witnessed the altercation. He said no one else witnessed it. At the time of
the incident the youth that were originally present had already left the building.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: CA 1 stated IL Youth G physically attacked him and busted his
lip at a community center. IL Youth G referred to the incident as
an “altercation” and refused to provide any details. There were
no other identifiable witnesses.
Due to a lack of evidence, whether or not CA 1 lacks the ability
to perform his duties as Chief Administrator cannot be
determined at this time.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION 2:
IL Youth D stabbed a man and a former IL youth after they broke into the provider
home on Lakewood Street in Detroit between 7am - 3pm. IL Youths J and L
cleaned up the blood.
5

INVESTIGATION:
*Note – Per DHHS contract, a CCO employee is required to be present in the
provider home between the hours of 3pm – 7am daily. The contract does not
require an employee to be present from 7am – 3pm.
IL Youth J, age 18, has resided at the provider home on Lakewood Street in Detroit for
ten months. I interviewed him by phone on 6/29/20. I asked IL Youth J if he had
knowledge of a break-in, a stabbing or if he cleaned up any blood in the provider home.
He responded, “No. I’m lost. I don’t remember nothing like that.” I asked again if he
heard about or was aware of a break-in by a former IL youth. He said, “No.”
IL Youth D, age 17, has resided at the provider home on Lakewood Street in Detroit for
one year. He reportedly was AWOL from the home for five days prior to the interview. I
interviewed him by phone on 6/29/20. I asked IL Youth D if he was aware of a break-in
by a former IL Youth or anyone else. He responded, “No. I don’t know nothing about
that. I don’t know nothing about that.” I asked if he was aware of a stabbing in the
home. IL Youth D said, “I heard something about that two weeks ago…I forgot who told
me.” I asked if he remembered what he heard. He responded, “I do not know. I don’t
know. I work. I do my own thing. I got a baby. I got my girl. I be gone so long. I got
my own agenda.” I asked IL Youth D if he believes the provider home is a safe place
for IL youth to reside. He answered, “It is a safe place.”
I interviewed Licensee Designee (LD) 1 by phone on 6/16/20. I asked if she was
aware of any break-in and/or stabbing at the provider home on Lakewood Street. She
responded, “No. I don’t know nothing about that. I asked if there was any blood that
was cleaned up at the home. She said, “No.”
IL Youth L (Youth J’s brother), age 16, has resided at the provider home on Lakewood
Street in Detroit for eight months. I interviewed him by phone on 6/29/20. I asked IL
Youth L if he was aware of a break-in or stabbing at the provider home. He hesitated.
“I don’t know because I barely be here, but I did hear something like that.” I asked him
to elaborate.
IL Youth L said that someone stole his laptop, all of his shoes and clothing, and a
television belonging to the provider. He suspects a former IL youth took his items
because “someone saw him (in the community) with my shoes on.” IL Youth L
hypothesized a thief may have gained access to the home through a window with a
broken lock. He denied that anyone was stabbed in the home or that he cleaned up any
blood. IL Youth L said he did not report the theft to the police, but he believes LD 1
reported it. He did not know what day he discovered his belongings missing.
6

I re-interviewed LD 1 by phone on 6/30/20. She said IL Worker 1 informed her that IL
Youths J and L told her their laptops missing. LD 1 did not remember when IL Worker 1
told her this. “I wasn’t told clothes or shoes were missing. There was a television
missing but I believe it happened prior to that. I’ve had five televisions come up missing
since 2016.” LD 1 said she believes the five television were stolen by IL youth and sold.
She replaces the televisions when they go missing. LD 1 said the youth are able to
steal the homes’ property during the hours the homes are not staffed.
I asked LD 1 if there is a window is broken anywhere in the home on Lakewood, which I
was informed is a duplex. She said unidentified youth have broken off an interior
window lock on the first floor and that she has had it repaired several times. She said
the whole window was eventually replaced and in February 2020, the lock was broken
again. She did not know how many days the lock remained broken. However, each
time it is brought to her attention, she has it repaired.
I asked LD 1 if there are locks on the youth’s bedroom doors. She said the bedroom
doors do not lock for safety reasons. LD 1 added “Kids sign off that they are
responsible to protect their own belongings. If they have valuables, they are supposed
to take them with them. The youth are responsible to keep the (outer) doors locked
when staff are not there.”
IL Worker 1 has been a social service worker for four months. I interviewed her by
phone on 6/30/20. IL Worker 1 said she was aware IL Youth L’s laptop came up
missing. She was not sure if anyone reported this to the police.
IL Worker 1 affirmed that IL youth at Lakewood and the other provider home locations
frequently destroy property. She was not aware of any televisions were stolen from
provider homes.
IL Worker 1 said she believes the five provider’s homes are “very safe” for IL youth.
Asked how she determines safety, she said she talks to the neighbors, assures that
youth report all unusual incidents and visits the 13 youth on her caseload in their homes
twice a month even though it is not required at this time due to COVID-19 restrictions.
During each home visit, IL Worker 1 said she checks the basement, windows and
doors, and the bedrooms for drug paraphernalia. She said she does not feel the homes
require 24/7 staff supervision because her “youth sleep until 11am or noon during
COVID and otherwise are at work or school.”
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in
independent living consistent with the youth’s need for
supervision, as required by R 400.12504(2)(e).
7

ANALYSIS: The agency is required to provide a level of supervision
consistent with the needs of the youth. Given the break-ins and
thievery that is occurring outside of the time in which the house
is staffed, the agency is not providing supervision consistent
with the needs of the clients, or meeting the requirement of this
rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
No repeats
ADDITIONAL FINDING:
I requested the MISACWIS person IDs and names of the IL workers assigned to IL
Youths G, D, J and L from Jan – May 2020. There was more than one IL worker
assigned to two of the four youth during that period. The IL workers assigned to those
two youth no longer work for the agency. In fact, in addition to managing Community
Care Organization’s four IL provider homes, LD 1 said she also temporarily assumed
the role of IL worker for IL Youths G and D during the months of April and May.
The MISACWIS social work contacts showed IL Youths G, L and J were visited in the
provider home by IL workers monthly. However, there was no documentation that IL
Youth D was visited in the month of April 2020. LD 1 said she saw IL Youth D in the
home that month, but she did not document it as a home visit in the social work contacts
in MISACWIS. LD 1 further reported that due to the serious COVID outbreak in the city
of Detroit, the agency experienced a high turnover of both IL workers and provider
home staff (as required by DHHS contract) from March – May 2020.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the contract required by R
400.125010, continues to reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing expenditures.
ANALYSIS: There was no documentation in the MISACWIS social work
contacts that IL Youth D was visited by an IL worker to ensure
the home was safe and acceptable in April 2020.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8

CONSULTATION –
If youth safety is in jeopardy at any time, the IL worker or any other CCO employee
who becomes aware must notify the appropriate authority (i.e., law enforcement,
children’s protective services, adult protective services and/or the referral source)
immediately. Depending on the situation, the IL worker may need to recommend or
request that MDHHS move the youth to safety.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall have and follow a current program
statement that includes all of the following information:
(a) Types of living arrangements approved
(b) Eligibility requirements for a youth, including age and
level of physical, emotional, and intellectual functioning
and youth not appropriate for the program.
(e) Supervision
CONSULTATION CCO’s program statement/description should clearly indicate the
type of living arrangement(s) offered by the agency. In this
case, each arrangement is a group setting that provides no adult
supervision between the hours of 7am – 3pm daily. The
statement should describe the homes’ neighborhoods and
shared living spaces, and explain that large lockers are not
provided for youth to secure their belongings and that the
youths’ bedroom doors do not lock. The program statement
should be available to the referral source upon their request.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection
of independent living as the most appropriate
placement for the youth.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements
for the specific program the youth is placed
into.
(b)The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits
self-care potential.
9

(e ) An evaluation of a youth’s need for supervision
and a plan for providing the level of supervision
determined necessary.
TECHNICAL The eligibility requirements identified in this rule are determined
ASSISTANCE by CCO (the placing agency) not by the referring agency. CCO
must conduct a thorough assessment of each youth prior to
accepting and placing each youth in one of its group provider
homes.
First CCO must determine and document the rationale for
selecting independent living for the youth vs foster care (with a
relative or non-relative) or residential placement. Secondly, they
must determine and document the rationale for selecting a
group independent living arrangement vs an independent living
arrangement with an individual appropriate home provider,
friend or relative.
If a group independent living arrangement is determined as
most appropriate, how the youth meets CCO’s specific program
requirements and the basis for concluding the youth exhibits
self-care potential must be documented before the youth is
placed.
Finally CCO must evaluate the youth for his/her individual need
for supervision and devise a plan to provide the level of adult
supervision determined necessary. This evaluation and plan
must also be documented.
RECOMMENDATION:
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is submitted, I recommend this agency
continue its current licensing status.
July 13, 2020
________________________________________
Deborah Will Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
10

October 14, 2020
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
11
